event_registry_properties.name: action
event_registry_properties.item:
Schedule a repair procedure to replace the affected CPU, the identity of which can be determined using fmdump -v -u <EVENT_ID>.

The event-id can be found in the EVENT-ID field of the message. For example:

    EVENT-ID: 3127744a-095e-cc87-9d6b-fc805ef2f437
event_registry_properties.name: description
event_registry_properties.item: A fault has been detected in the FPU of this CPU.
event_registry_properties.name: details
event_registry_properties.item:
The Message ID:   %MSGID% indicates that the Solaris[TM] Fault Manager has determined that a CPU has suffered an FPU failure. The Diagnostic Engine (DE) has triggered an automatic FMA response to disable and isolate this CPU from the configuration in order to prevent repeat errors and increase the system's total Availability.

Arrangements should be made to replace the Field Replaceable Unit (FRU) on which the suspect CPU is located. Refer to the information displayed in the FRU: field of the fmdump output. For example: 

    # fmdump -vu 3127744a-095e-cc87-9d6b-fc805ef2f437
TIME                 UUID                                 SUNW-MSG-ID
Nov 23 09:43:58.3287 3127744a-095e-cc87-9d6b-fc805ef2f437 SUN4U-8000-QY
   100%  fault.cpu.ultraSPARC-IV.fpu
          FRU: hc:///component=SB0
         rsrc: rsrc: cpu:///cpuid=0/serial=D27081B5443

Sun Fire Midrange and High End notes:

There may be additional fault information logged by System Controller Application (ScApp) on Sun Fire[TM] Midrange (3800, 48x0, 6800, v1280, E2900, E4900, E6900) and System Management Services (SMS) on High End (12K, 15K, E20K, E25K) Servers. Availability enhancements (called AVL) have been integrated into ScApp 5.19.0 and SMS 1.5 to allow FMA/AVL interaction to coexist.
